Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with reminders from my stepdad: “Don’t forget, dinner at six. It means a lot to your mom.” My stepsister had already texted, “You’re coming, right? It’s been ages since we all sat together.” I knew how important these gatherings were, especially since I’d joined the family only a year ago. They wanted me there, present, part of the new whole.

But just as I was about to leave, my work phone rang. The plant manager’s voice was tense: “The main unit’s down again. Sensor errors. We’re losing time—can you get here ASAP?” I could picture the blinking red lights, the anxious faces of the crew waiting for me to fix what no one else could. Production was at a standstill, and every minute counted.

My jacket hung over one arm, car keys in hand, I stood frozen in the hallway. Family or factory? Both needed me, both expected me to show up, to be reliable. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment in my stepmom’s eyes against the urgency in my manager’s voice, torn between two worlds that refused to wait.
